sub_title: Geochemist | Researcher | Lab & Data Analyst | Technology | Pragmatic | Positive
summary:
After completing both my BSc (Milano) and research MSc (Amsterdam) in the field of Earth Sciences, I worked for the last 2 years in academia as a researcher and lab/data analyst (2021-2022). 

My passion for geology has long-lasting roots that stretches into my youth. I come from a small village nestled among the italian Alps and my adolescence was imbued with long walks in the wilderness that stimulated my curiosity and taught me the importance of calm and preparation when facing difficult moments. My bachelor in geology allowed me to aquired a thorough understanding of the complex processes shaping the Earth at the surface and deep level.

For my master, I decided to follow a track in geochemistry, in order to integrate the study of geology with two other passions of mine: chemistry and technology. This brought me to closely work with mass spectrometers and other powerful thechnolgies and work in clean labs and shaped the direction of my following work exeperience. After my studies, I worked in academia for two years, during which I developed a new analytical method to measure compostions, delivered high quality data and collaborated and guided an excellent international research team. 

For my next job position, I very much welcome the opportunity to learn new skills and apply my curiosity and expertise into fields of work that are prompted to create a more connected, equal and sustainable world.

projects:
[{'title': 'MSc Thesis | grade: 9/10', 'date': {'start': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'Project title:
"Textural variation and purple-orange garnets in Jwaneng peridotitic mantle xenoliths, Kaapvaal Craton."

Mineral major–trace element and Sr–Nd–Hf isotope data of 22 peridotitic xenoliths were used to infer the tectono-magmatic events that affected the lithospheric mantle beneath Jwaneng (Botswana). These rocks record both ancient (Proterozoic, from 2-1.5 Ga) and relatively recent (240 Ma) extensive metasomatic overprinting that likely obscured the more ancient nature of this portion of lithosphere. Notable differences were observed with mantle xenoliths from South Africa (e.g., Kimberley). This thesis provides evidence that multi-stage and severe re-fertilisation processes largely contributed to make Jwaneng Mine the most profitable diamond mine in the world. For this project I processed data from several analytical instruments (EMP, ICPMS, TIMS, MC-ICPMS) and conducted a fieldtrip in Botswana in collaboration with Debswana diamond company.
', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Matteo', 'last_name': 'Branchetti', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geochemist | Researcher | Lab & Data Analyst | Technology | Pragmatic | Positive'}]}, {'title': 'MSc Research Project. | grade: 9/10', 'date': {'start': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}}, 'description': 'Project title: 
"Geochemical and Sr–Nd–Hf isotope constraints on garnet harzburgites xenoliths from the SCLM beneath Kimberley, South Africa."

This project investigated 39 garnet harzburgites from Kimberley lithospheric mantle (South Africa). The low-metasomatised nature of these rocks allowed to study ancient processes, older than 3 billion years. Based on multiple radiometric methods and major–trace element analyses, garnets have been formed and destroyed during at least 4 different events: three times in the Archaean (>2.5 Ga) and shortly prior to kimberlite eruption 91 Ma ago. For this project I processed data from several analytical instruments (XRF, EMP, ICPMS, TIMS, MC-ICPMS) and conducted a fieldtrip in South Africa in collaboration with DeBeers Group. 
', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Matteo', 'last_name': 'Branchetti', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Geochemist | Researcher | Lab & Data Analyst | Technology | Pragmatic | Positive'}]}]
